snippet: The government’s authority to sweep up bulk phone data in the hunt for terrorists expired temporarily at 12:01 a.m. Monday, but the Senate indicated that legislation to curtail the program is likely to pass this week.
abstract: Provisions of Patriot Act allowing government to amass phone records temporarily expires following caustic Senate session in which Sen Rand Paul blocked extension; revised edition of law, which will curtail some bulk data collection by National Security Agency, is likely to pass in coming week; developments reflect profound shift in American attitudes toward data collection since days following Sept 11 attacks.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JONATHAN WEISMAN

lead_paragraph: The government’s authority to sweep up bulk phone data in the hunt for terrorists expired temporarily at 12:01 a.m. Monday, but the Senate indicated that legislation to curtail the program is likely to pass this week.

headline.main: Key Parts of Patriot Act Expire Temporarily as Senate Moves Toward Limits on Spying
headline.print_headline: Senate, in Reversal, Moves Toward Limits on Spying
